Shi Huida, Shi Huida, with the surname Liu, originally named Sahe, was a person from Lishi in Xihe, Bingzhou.
He liked hunting when young.

At the age of thirty-one, he suddenly died temporarily and revived after a day, fully seeing the suffering of hell. He saw a monk who was his teacher in the previous life, who expounded the Dharma and instructed him, telling him to leave the household life and go to Danyang, Kuaiji, and Wujun to find the image of AÅ›oka's stÅ«pa to pay homage and repent, in order to repent his past sins.
After waking up, he immediately left the household life to study the Way and changed his name to Huida.
He diligently practiced meritorious deeds, taking paying homage and repenting as the priority.
During the Nikan era of the Jin Dynasty, he arrived in the capital city.
Previously, Emperor Jianwen of the Jin dynasty built a three-storied pagoda at Changgan Temple. After the pagoda was completed, it emitted light every evening.
Dashi reached Yuecheng and looked around. He saw that the top of this pagoda had a unique color. He then went to pay homage, earnestly praying morning and evening.
At night, he saw light coming from under the pagoda. He reported it to the people and they dug together. They dug down about one zhang and found three stone steles.
The central stele was covered in the middle. There was an iron case, and inside the silver case, there was a golden case. Inside the golden case, there were three Å›arÄ«ra.
There was also a fingernail and a hair. The hair was several feet long when stretched out, and when rolled up, it formed a spiral. The light and color dazzled.
This was one of the 84,000 pagodas built by King AÅ›oka of the Zhou Jingwang period.
Since both monks and laypeople marveled at it, they erected another pagoda to the west of the old pagoda and enshrined the Å›arÄ«ra.
In the 16th year of Taiyuan of the Jin dynasty, Emperor Xiaowu added three more stories.

Moreover, in the Xianhe period of the Jin dynasty, Gao Kui, the Governor of Danyang, excavated a golden statue without a halo or pedestal from the waters under Zhang Houqiao Bridge. The craftsmanship was exquisite.
On the front, there were Sanskrit inscriptions stating that it was made by the fourth daughter of King AÅ›oka.

Kui loaded the statue and returned to the Changgan Lane, but the ox refused to move further. It was not under human control, so he let the ox go wherever it wanted, and it went straight to Changgan Temple.
After that, for several years, a fisherman named Zhang Jishi from Linhai found a copper lotus pedestal floating on the water at the mouth of the sea. He immediately took it and sent it to the county.
The county reported it to the court, and an imperial decree ordered the pedestal to be placed under the statue. It fit perfectly.
Later, five monks from the Western Regions visited Kui and said:
In the past, we obtained a statue of King AÅ›oka in India, but when we reached Ye, we encountered chaos and hid it on the riverbank.
When the roads were opened, we searched for it but lost it.
Recently, I had a dream saying that the image has already emerged in Jiangdong and was obtained by Gao Kui.
Therefore, I traveled far across mountains and seas, wishing to see and pay homage to it.
Kui then led them to Changgan, and the five people saw the image. They wept with tears, and the image emitted light, illuminating the hall.
The five people said:
Originally there was a halo, which is now in a distant place, and will also arrive soon.
In the first year of Xian'an in the Jin dynasty, Dong Zongzhi, a pearl diver from Hepu County in Jiaozhou, obtained a Buddha's light from the seabed.
The magistrate reported it to the throne, and Emperor Jianwen of the Jin ordered it to be offered to the image.
The hole and the light had the same color.
For more than forty years, auspicious signs appeared in the east and west, and the halo and pedestal were finally complete.
Dharmaraká¹£a, considering the miraculous nature of the image, redoubled his efforts.
Later, he traveled to Wuxian in the east and paid homage to the stone image.
It was in the first year of Jianxing, the year of Guiyou, at the end of the Western Jin Dynasty, that the images floated in the mouth of the Hudu River in the Wu area.
Fishermen suspected them to be sea gods, and invited shamans to welcome them, but then the wind and waves became violent, and they returned in fear.
At that time, there were followers of Laozi of the Yellow Emperor who said they were the gods of the Celestial Master, and they went together to receive them, but the drifting waves were as before.
Later, a Buddhist layman named Zhu Ying from Wu County heard about this and sighed:
Could it not be the manifestation of the Great Awakened One?
He then purified himself and went to the mouth of the Hudu River with silk nun and several believers from Dongyun Temple.
He bowed his head in utmost sincerity, sang praises, and reached virtue, and then the wind and waves calmed down.
He saw two people floating on the river from afar, and they were stone images. On their backs were inscriptions, one named Vaisravana and the other Kasyapa.
He then brought them back and placed them in Tongxuan Temple.
The gentlemen and commoners of Wu admired its spiritual wonders, and many turned their hearts to it.
Damo stayed at Tongxuan Temple for three years, diligently worshipping day and night without a moment's rest.
After a while, he went to Mount Tiantai in Zhejiang to pay homage to the stupa.
This stupa was also built by King AÅ›oka, but it had been abandoned for many years, with only the foundation remaining.
Damo focused his mind and thoughts, and suddenly saw a divine light shining. He then repaired and built the stupa, and no birds dared to perch near it.
Those who hunted or fished near the temple would always come up empty-handed. The monks and laypeople who heard about this all changed their beliefs.
Later, the prefect Meng Yi further expanded the temple.
Damo traveled to various places to pay homage, and often received auspicious signs. He was diligent and persevering, never changing throughout his life.
Later, his whereabouts were unknown.
Shi Huimian, Shi Huimian, a person from Hebei, was kind-hearted and had no expression of joy or anger.
He always practiced meditation and recitation, and encouraged meritorious deeds as his constant practice.

In the beginning of the Taiyuan era of the Jin dynasty, he established a temple on Ping Mountain in Wuling, with more than twenty monks, subsisting on vegetarian food, secluded and secluded, forever cut off from human paths.
In the fourteenth year of Taiyuan, he passed away.

After his death, someone entered the mountains below Mount Wudang and saw him, with a very cheerful expression, entrusting a message to the monks of the temple, not allowing the temple's affairs to be neglected.
Since then, the temple has always heard the sound of a bell in the air, responding to the time, and the assembly of monks has never been missed.

Huizhi was diligent and austere, with precepts and principles. Later, he stopped eating grains and only ate pine and cypress, and then ascended the mountain to shed his cicada-like outer skin.
Shi Huili, Shi Huili, unknown person.
During the Yonghe period of the Jin dynasty, he came to roam in the capital.
He always begged for food, practiced asceticism, and cultivated blessings.
In the Xingning period of the Jin dynasty, he petitioned to use the place of Tao as the Waguan Temple.
The foundation of the stupa was first marked, which is now to the west of the stupa.

Every evening the mark would be moved east by more than ten steps. In the morning, they would take it back, but it would move again. They secretly watched it and saw a person wearing a red robe and a military cap pulling out the mark and placing it in the east, and then building the stupa at that place, which is now the location of the stupa.
The inscription said:
Thirty years after the establishment of the temple, it will be burned by a heavenly fire.
In the twenty-first year of the Taiyuan era of Emperor Xiaowu of the Jin dynasty, in the seventh month, a fire spontaneously broke out at night.
The monks in the temple, dozens of them, did not know anything about it. In the morning, they saw that the stupa had already turned into a pile of ashes.
The emperor said:
This is an inauspicious sign for the country.
He then ordered Yang Fashang, Li Xu, and others to quickly repair it.
In the ninth month, the emperor passed away.
There were five statues made by Dai Andao, and a sixteen-foot golden statue repaired by Dai Yong.
In the past, when the cast image was first completed, the face and head were unusually thin. The craftsmen did not know what to do. They invited Yong to come and see it.
Yong said:
It's not that the face is thin, but that the arms and shoulders are too fat.
After they trimmed the arms and shoulders, the facial features became full on their own. The craftsmen all marveled.
There were also two feet and four inches of jade images from the Lion Country, all of which were there.
In the past, the king of the Lion Country heard that the Jin Emperor Xiaowu was diligent in upholding the Dharma, so he sent the Å›ramaá¹‡a Tamo Yi to offer this Buddha image from afar.
It took more than ten years on the road before it reached the Jin Dynasty during the Yixi period.

Sima Tuo Wang Mi once entered the palace and saw that at the gate of Dongye, there were people playing with dice in a temple. Wherever the dice landed, there was always light coming out. He found it strange and ordered them to dig there, and they obtained a golden image, seven feet and two inches tall including the halo and pedestal.

Hui Min then reported this to Emperor Gaozu of the Liu Song Dynasty, who welcomed him into the palace for offerings. At the end of the Jingping era of the Liu Song Dynasty, he was sent to Waguan Temple. He is now moved to Longguang Temple.
Shi Huishou, a person from Anle.
During the Xingning period of the Jin Dynasty, he came to the capital city.
He ate vegetarian food, practiced asceticism, and always cultivated meritorious deeds.
Once, when he was passing by Wang Tan's garden, he dreamed of building a temple in the garden every night. He had this dream many times.
Huishou wanted to go to Wang to ask for a place to build a single room, but he did not dare speak. He first told Song Qi, a guest who guarded the garden.
Qi said:
The Wang family's garden, I'm afraid it's not what you're planning.
Huishou said:
If it can truly move the heart, why worry about not getting it?
He then went to Wang and told him.
Wang was overjoyed and immediately agreed.
He first built a small hut. Every evening he dreamed again of a blue dragon coming from the south, transforming into a temple pillar.
He went to the Xin'an River to test the novice monk, and saw a long piece of wood floating down the river.
Huiyi said:
This must be the one I saw!
He then hired people to pull it up, erected it as a stupa, and built a single-story structure around it.
Monks and laypeople gathered, all marveling at its miraculous nature.
Tan immediately donated the garden to become a temple, naming it Anle Temple after Huiyi's hometown.

To the east was the residence of Wang Ya, the Prefect of Danyang, to the west was the residence of Liu Dou, the Governor of Dongyan, and to the south was the residence of Fan Ning, the Governor of Yuzhang. All of them donated their land to build the temple.
Later, monks Daojing, Daojing, and others further renovated it, and it remains magnificent to this day.
Shi Seng Hui, Shi Seng Hui, unknown person.
From a young age, he enjoyed cultivating meritorious deeds.
During the Yixi period of the Jin dynasty, he established a temple together with Xing Changsheng of Chang'an in the Puwu village of the capital city.
At first, he built several thatched huts in a remote place and gathered monks to hold a vegetarian feast.
In the middle of the night, the two lamps in the hall suddenly moved forward by several dozen steps on their own, with the oil supply remaining the same without spilling.
The great assembly was amazed, and when they inquired of the elders, they all said that the place where the lamps moved was the foundation of the stupa built by a foreign monk in the past.
Therefore, they built on that spot.
Because the lamps moved as an auspicious sign, the temple was named Chongming Temple.
Shi Sengyi, a monk, was originally from Yuhang in Wuxing.ğŸ”½He had faith and understanding from a young age and had the determination to transcend the world.
He first became a monk at Lushan Temple and studied under Huiyuan.
He lived on vegetarian food and practiced asceticism, and was respected by his fellow monks.
Later, he traveled to Guanzhong and studied under KumÄrajÄ«va again. He studied various sÅ«tras, vinayas, and Å›Ästras, and recited the Lotus SÅ«tra.
In the thirteenth year of Yixi of the Jin dynasty, he traveled to Kuaiji with fellow monks such as Tanzai, exploring the mountains and rivers.
Arriving at the northwest of Mount Qin, he saw five peaks clustered together, resembling Mount Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a, so he built a grass hut and called it Lotus Sutra Monastery.
Prefect Meng Yi and wealthy man Chen Zai both admired his virtue and helped him complete the monastery.
Wing lived on vegetarian food and drank from streams for over thirty years, passing away in the twenty-seventh year of the Yuanjia era of the Song dynasty, at the age of seventy.
A stele was erected at the mountain temple to commemorate his remaining virtue.
Kong Huan of Kuaiji composed the inscription.
Wing's fellow traveler, monk Tanzai, later moved to the north of Mount Qin and called it Joyful Forest Monastery.
Shaoxiang and Guannian, both renowned monks of Mount Dongyue, also stayed there together.
At that time, there was Shi Daogong, who was from the Langye clan and a great-grandson of Wang Xizhi, the right general of the Jin dynasty.
He left the world and became a monk, feeling affection for the monks.
He lived on Mount Yeya, establishing the Xilian Temple.
Later, in order to make offerings to the monks, he renounced the precepts and single-mindedly observed the ten precepts.
Shi Senghong, Shi Senghong was a person from Yuzhou and stayed at Waguan Temple in the capital.
When young, he cultivated his body and was neat and clean.
Later, he led those with affinity to create a sixteen-foot golden statue. When casting was completed, the mold had yet to be opened.
At that time, the ban on copper was very strict at the end of the Jin dynasty, and those who violated it would surely die.
At that time, Song Wu was the chancellor. Senghong was imprisoned in the chancellor's office due to the crime. He only recited the Guanyin Sutra and single-mindedly took refuge in the Buddha statue.
At night, he dreamed that the cast statue came and patted Senghong's head, asking:
Are you afraid?
Senghong said:
I think I will surely die.
The statue said:
Do not worry.
He saw that the chest of the statue had a spot about one foot square where the copper had melted.
The execution was scheduled, with the prefectural army commander overseeing the killing, but the ox ran and the cart broke, so the date was set again.
Later, an order came from Pengcheng saying:
Do not kill yet. The monk Hong can be pardoned.
Thus, he was spared.
When he returned and opened the mold, he saw that the Buddha's chest indeed had a burn mark.
Hong later died from ascetic practices.
Shi Sengliang, Shi Sengliang, unknown person.
Renowned from a young age for his precepts and practices.
Desiring to create a sixteen-foot gold statue, the copper was insufficient, not something that could be accomplished by small donations.

Hearing that there were many copper implements in the temple of Wu Zixu by the Copper River in the Xiangzhou area, and that the temple was very awe-inspiring, no one dared approach it, Liang heard about it and went there.
He informed Prefect Zhang Shao, borrowing a hundred strong men and ten large boats.
Shao said:
The temple has miraculous efficacy, those who violate it will surely die.
Moreover, it is guarded by barbarian people, how can it be obtained?
Liang said:ğŸ”½If I die, I will die. I have long been disgusted with this body. I only fear that I will not be able to complete the Buddha's appearance.
If there is merit, it will be shared with the donor.
If there is any fault, I will take full responsibility.
Shao then provided people and boats. They traveled for three days and three nights to reach the temple.

Liang and the laborers all went in together. Before reaching the temple building by twenty steps, there were two copper cauldrons, each holding over a hundred hu. Inside was a giant snake over ten zhang long, emerging to block the path.
Liang then straightened his demeanor, held his staff, and chanted a few dozen words of blessings. The snake suddenly disappeared.
Soon he saw a person holding a bamboo tablet coming out, saying he heard that:
The Dharma Master's Way and virtue are not ordinary, and the matter of cultivating merit is heavy. Now I specially come to rejoice.
Then he had people carry it away.
The temple copper was so much that he took only one in ten, and the boat was already full.
Only at the head of the divine bed there was a spittoon, inside of which there was a lizard about two feet long, sometimes coming out and sometimes entering.
The discussants all said that the spirit most loved this object, so Liang did not take it, and thus left. He encountered very favorable wind and water.
By the time the various barbarians informed each other and chased after him, they were no longer able to catch up.
Returning to the capital, the casting of the image was completed, but only the flame light was not yet ready.
Emperor Wen of the Liu Song Dynasty had a golden foil halo made for it and placed it in Pengcheng Temple.
By the time of the Taishi period of the Liu Song Dynasty, Emperor Ming moved the image to Xiangfu Temple, where it still remains today.
Shi Fayi, a person from Jiangzuo.
He liked to create blessings and built fifty-three temples.
During the Yixi period of the Jin Dynasty, Zhu Yingzi, the Master of Ceremonies on Mount Zhong.
Previously, Sun En's followers who established a righteous cause hid in this mountain and gave a small portion of the outer land to Yi to build a temple, which was called Yanxian Temple.
Later, Bei Du came and went to this temple, saying:
This place will soon have various changes, and later it will be good.
The land is opposite to the heavenly realm, making it easy to create meritorious karma.
Soon after, it was burned by a forest fire.
Later, Qi Xie and Zhang Yin used the instructions of Bei Du, as recorded in the biography of Du.
Then, he went to the mountains with Yi, wanting to build again, but there was no water, so it was not suitable to stay.
Yi thought of the words of Bei Du, and earnestly made offerings and repented, begging for the water of the Western Paradise.
After three days, his sincerity became even greater.
Suddenly, he heard a sound, and something fell to the ground.
Yi feared it was gold or silk, so he had people dig down two feet, and clear water gushed forth, forming a stream that never dried up. Then, he built a temple there.
Later, it is unknown where Yi passed away.
Shi Huijing, Shi Huijing, a person from Nanhai.

In his youth, he traveled and studied in Jing and Chu, and also extensively understood the scriptures and treatises. However, he always took meritorious deeds as his duty, so he did not fully accomplish the study of principles.
Whatever she did, she always built stupas and images, and helped with various projects.
Later, she returned to her hometown and repaired Yunfeng and Yong'an temples.
Jing was strict in observing the precepts and had a stern and upright character. Therefore, monks and nuns from outside the mountain range all followed her for instruction.
Later, she was ordered to be the leader of the monks and nuns, and her guidance was effective.
There was a slave son and novice monk of Jing who were suddenly struck by a ghost. Later, a mountain spirit appeared to Jing and fully apologized for their mistakes, saying:
My subordinates did not understand and recklessly disturbed the Dharma master's relatives.
After a while, everything returned to normal.
Whatever meritorious deeds she undertook, she dedicated them all to the Western Paradise.
On the day of her death, there was a strange fragrance in the room that lingered for a long time before disappearing.
Shi Fasheng, Shi Fasheng, was from Guangzhou.
He initially lived in the Northern Temple, which had been dilapidated for many years. Fasheng led those withç·£ to repair it and renamed it Yanxiang.
Later, he entered Cangwei Mountain and founded a temple. After the temple was completed, two boys came hand in hand and sang:
Cangwei has morality and virtue, and the joy and happiness are not yet over.
After saying this, they suddenly disappeared.
The entire temple was amazed and all marveled at the spiritual wonders.
After Xian entered meditation, he suddenly saw a person come and say:
The temple bell's hanging rope is about to break, why don't you fix it?
Xian startled and got up to look, it was about to fall to the ground, he caught it with his hands, and it was not broken.
Since Xian left home, he always encouraged the practice of meritorious deeds, and his mind rested in meditation and precepts, never violating the rules.
Later, it is unknown where he ended up.
Shi Faxian, whose surname was Xu, was a person from Yanshui in Xihe.
He first followed his uncle to Liangzhou and then left home.
In the 16th year of the Yuanjia era, he finally arrived in the capital city and stayed at Upper Dinglin Temple.
He had a thorough understanding of the scriptures and precepts and was determined and persevering in his practice.
He was very good at guiding and rescuing.

Xian's practice of the precepts was pure and his virtue was a model for others.
Langya's Wang Su, Wang Rong, Wuguo's Zhang Rong, Zhang Quan, the monk Huiling, Zhizang, and others all bowed their bodies and joined their palms to revere his admonitions and teachings.
Xian, in the Yongming period, was ordered to be the head monk of Changgan Temple, together with Xuanchang, and was in charge of the south bank.

Later, Xian was ordered to the three prefectures of Wu and was asked to select two monks. Chang also went east and reiterated the method of receiving the precepts.

At that time, the two monks Chang and Xian both studied the Vinaya from a young age and did not compete with the world. When they spoke with Emperor Wu, they always addressed him by name and did not sit.
Later, Seng Zhong met the emperor at the Qianhe Hall. The emperor asked Seng Zhong about his well-being, and Seng Zhong replied, This poor monk has been suffering from illness.
The emperor disapproved and asked Wang Jian, the Minister of the Secretariat:
When the monks of the past spoke with the emperor, what did they call themselves?
Did they sit in the main hall?
Wang Jian replied:
Since the Buddhist Dharma had not yet flourished during the Han and Wei Dynasties, there are no records of this.
Since the pseudo-states, it has become more prevalent. They all call themselves poor monks and also sit together.

During the middle period, there were Yubi and Huan Xuan who all wanted to make monks pay respect. The court discussions were in turmoil, and the matters were all put on hold.
During the early years of the Song Dynasty, they also made people pay respect, but it was soon discontinued.
Since then, they often sit together and call themselves poor monks.
The emperor said:

The two monks Chang and Xian, with such spiritual accomplishments, still used their own names. How much more so for others? Bowing to them would be too much, but using their names is not objectionable.
From then on, monks all used their own names before emperors. This began with Chang and Xian.
Chang passed away in the first year of the Jianwu era at the age of seventy-five.
Xian died in the last year of the Jianwu era. He was buried together with Chang on the eastern side of Zhong Mountain.
Xian's disciple Seng You built a stele beside the tomb. Wu Xing Shen Yue, the Prefect of Danyang, composed the inscription.
The Buddha's tooth relic and image that Xian obtained in the Western Regions were both at Upper Dinglin Temple.

In the third month of the first year of the Puzhou era, several people armed with weapons knocked on the door in the middle of the night, claiming that a slave of the Prince of Linchuan had rebelled and someone reported that he was on the Buddha's tooth relic pavilion, asking to open the pavilion to inspect it. The temple authorities immediately followed their words and opened the pavilion.

The master arrived in front of the Buddha's tooth seat, opened the casket to take out the tooth, made three prostrations, wrapped the tooth with a brocade handkerchief, and left going east around the mountain.
Until now, it is still unknown where it is.
Shi Seng Hu Shi Seng Hu was originally from Shan County, Kuaiji.
He left home at a young age and always focused on hardship. He was strict in precepts and pure in conduct.
Later, he lived at Yinyue Temple on Mount Shicheng.
To the north of the temple, there was a green cliff, straight up for several tens of zhang. In the center, there was a shape like the Buddha's flame light.
Above it, there were clumps of trees with crooked trunks hanging over the cliff.
Whenever Seng Hu walked to the cliff, he would always see a brilliant light and hear the sounds of stringed instruments, singing, and praises.

He then held up an incense burner, made a vow, and wished to carve a ten-zhang stone Buddha on the mountain, to respectfully emulate Maitreya's thousand-foot appearance, allowing all those with karmic affinity to see the three assemblies together.
During the Jianwu era of the Northern Qi, he gathered monks and laypeople and began carving the statue.
After years of carving, only the face was roughly completed.
Soon after, Hu died of illness.
Before his death, he vowed:
What I have created was originally not intended to be accomplished in one lifetime.
In my second life, may my wish be fulfilled.
Later, a monk named Sengshu continued the unfinished work, but lacked the necessary resources and was unable to complete it.

In the sixth year of the Tianjian era of the Liang dynasty, Lu Xian of Wu Commandery, the magistrate of Shifeng, was returning home after resigning from office. He spent the night by the stream in Shan, where it was dark and rainy. Lu Xian was frightened and fell asleep. He suddenly dreamed of three monks who came to tell him:
Your faith and righteousness are firm and upright, so you will naturally be safe.
The Prince of Jian'an is suffering from an illness that has not been cured. If you can complete the stone statue being carved by Monk Seng Hu of Shan County, he will surely recover.
The truth of the unseen world is not false. You should reveal this to him.

After returning to the capital for a year, they gradually forgot their previous dream. Later, when they went out the door, they saw a monk who said he was staying overnight after listening to the lecture. He said:
Do you still remember the matter of King Jian'an in Shanxi that you entrusted last year?
Xian was frightened at the time and replied:
I don't remember.
The monk laughed and said:
You should think about it again.
He then took his leave.
Xian realized he was no ordinary person, so he took off his shoes and followed him, chasing after him for a hundred steps, but suddenly he could not be seen.
Xian suddenly understood and fully remembered his previous dream. He was the third monk he saw in Shanxi.
Xian immediately reported it to King Jian'an, who then reported it to the emperor, and ordered Vinaya Master Sengyou to be in charge of the image project.
The king then deepened his faith and was filled with joy, donating gold and silk, vowing to complete it.

Before Sengyou arrived, on one day, the monk Huitong of the temple dreamed of a great deity in black robes, with a very imposing retinue, standing at the location of the niche, discussing the proportions. When he woke up the next morning, Vinaya Master Sengyou arrived. The divine response was like this.

Originally, when Seng Hu created the niche, it was dug too shallow, so he scraped it in five zhang and added the ushnisha and body features. When the polishing was about to be completed, in the middle of the night, at the location of the myrobalan fruit, the color turned red and protruded.
Now, at the location of the myrobalan fruit on the chest of the statue, gold leaf is still not applied, and the red color remains.
The statue was completed in the spring of the twelfth year of Tianjian and finished in the spring of the fifteenth year.

The seated body is five zhang tall, and the standing form is ten zhang. In front of the niche, a three-story platform was built, and a gate, pavilion, hall, and other buildings were constructed, along with establishing various foundations to provide for the offerings.
The people from the four directions and the commoners all brought incense and flowers, gathering from thousands of miles away.
The tracks of offerings and comings and goings were filled with traces.
After the image was completed, the illness of King Jian'an gradually improved, and the original soldier recovered.
The king was later enfeoffed, and he is now the King of Nanping.
Shi Fayue, a monk of pure precepts,
was ordered to be the leader of monks in the late Qi dynasty, and stayed at Zhengjue Temple in the capital.
He diligently cultivated meritorious deeds, and was respected by the four groups of Buddhists.

Fayue once heard that there was an eighteen-foot golden image at Songwang Temple in Pengcheng, which was created by Wang Zhongde, the General of the Cavalry and Governor of Xuzhou of the Song dynasty, and its craftsmanship was considered the best in Jiangzuo.
